title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4627-4628: A Ridge Stop in the Boxworks
summary: Earth planning date: Monday Aug. 11, 2025 Written by Lucy Lim, Planetary Scientist at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center On the Curiosity team, we’re continuing our exploration of the boxwork-forming region in Gale Crater. A successful 25-meter drive (about 82 feet) brought the rover from the “peace sign” ridge intersection to a new ridge site. […]
detailed_news: A successful 25-meter drive brought the rover from the “peace sign” ridge intersection to a new ridge site. Mastcam observations of a potential incipient hollow (“Laguna Miniques”) APXS and MAHLI measurements were planned to explore the local bedrock at two points.

title: NASA Seeks Industry Feedback on Fission Surface Power
summary: As part of the agency’s initiative to return humanity to the Moon and eventually send the first astronaut – an American – to Mars, NASA is surveying industry for interest and feedback on a fission surface power system, through a Request for Information issued Thursday. Earlier this month, NASA declared its intent to put a […]
detailed_news: NASA is surveying industry for interest and feedback on a fission surface power system. Earlier this month, NASA declared its intent to put a nuclear reactor on the Moon by the mid-2030s. Nuclear power is a key element for NASA’s Artemis missions and supporting a robust lunar economy.

title: Astronauts Plant Seed Pillows in New Space Agriculture Study
summary: When the Crew-11 astronauts launched to the International Space Station on August 1, 2025, they carried with them another chapter in space farming: the latest VEG-03 experiments, complete with seed pillows ready for planting. Growing plants provides nutrition for astronauts, as well as psychological benefits that help maintain crew morale during missions. During VEG-03 MNO, […]
detailed_news: Astronauts will plant Wasabi mustard greens, Red Russian Kale, and Dragoon lettuce. The experiment takes place inside Veggie, a chamber about the size of carry-on luggage. Fresh food will become critical as astronauts venture farther from Earth on missions to the Moon and Mars.

title: Skyrora weighs options on the path to the UK’s first vertical launch
summary:
Edinburgh-based Skyrora was granted its Spaceflight Operator Licence from the UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)…
The post Skyrora weighs options on the path to the UK’s first vertical launch appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Edinburgh-based Skyrora was granted its Spaceflight Operator Licence from the UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) on August 5. The license authorizes one initial launch, and covers up to 16 flights per year from the SaxaVord spaceport situated 80 km to the northeast of mainland Scotland on the northernmost of the Shetland Islands. Despite being awarded the long-awaited UK license, the company might yet decide to conduct a second launch of Skylark L from another site. Skyrora has developed a containerized ‘spaceport in a box’ concept, which means that it doesn’t especially need a pad to launch from. The company’s first vehicle, the Skylark Nano, launched from the Kildermorie Estate in Ross-shire in August 2018. The relationship with the Langanes Peninsula of Iceland began with the launch of the two-stage Skylarks. Skylark L is the company’s second rocket, following the Skylark Micro. The vehicle stands 11.6 m tall and 0.7 m wide. It is powered by a combination of High-Test Peroxide (HTP) and kerosene. Skyrora uses in-house distillation processes to reach the strength needed. In 2019, Skyrora located and returned parts of this rocket’s first stage to the UK, marking its 48th anniversary. Although it offers a little less performance than when using cryogenics for oxidizers, HTP can be stored at room temperature.

title: After Storied 34 Year Career, Steve Platnick Retires from NASA
summary: Dr. Steven “Steve” Platnick stepped down from his role at NASA on August 8, 2025, after more than three decades of public service. Steve began his career at NASA as a physical scientist at Goddard Space Flight Center in 2002. He moved to the Earth Science Division in 2009, where he has served in various […]
detailed_news: Dr. Steven “Steve” Platnick stepped down from his role at NASA on August 8, 2025. Steve began his career at NASA as a physical scientist at Goddard Space Flight Center in 2002. He moved to the Earth Science Division in 2009, where he has served in various senior management roles. Steve has been supportive of the activities of NASA’s Science Support Office (SSO) He has participated in many NASA Science exhibits at both national and international scientific conferences. Steve has been a champion of continuing to retain a historical record of NASA meetings to maintain a chronology of advances made by different groups within the NASA Earth Science community. Steve has received numerous NASA Group Achievement Awards, including for the Cloud, Aerosol and Monsoon Processes Philippines Experiment (CAMP2Ex) Steve has published more than 150 scholarly articles. He began his career at the Joint Center for Earth Systems Technology (JCET) at University of Maryland Baltimore County in 1996.

title: Small Companies Win Big in NASA’s TechLeap Challenge
summary: NASA announced 10 winning teams for its latest TechLeap Prize — the Space Technology Payload Challenge — on June 26. The winners emerged from a record-breaking field of more than 200 applicants to earn cash prizes worth up to $500,000, if they have a flight-ready unit. Recipients may also have the opportunity to flight test […]
detailed_news: NASA announced 10 winning teams for its latest TechLeap Prize on June 26. The winners emerged from a record-breaking field of more than 200 applicants. Recipients may have the opportunity to flight test their technologies. The projects receive funding through the Commercially Enabled Rapid Space Science initiative.

title: New Research Connects Plant Nutrition and Astronaut Gut Health
summary: New research uncovers the connection between space agriculture and astronaut health. A study published in npj Microgravity shows how analyzing diverse datasets together can reveal insights that might otherwise be missed — in this case, linking space-grown food quality to astronaut nutrition and gut health. The paper reviewed previous studies of plants grown aboard the […]
detailed_news: The cosmic object you were looking for has disappeared beyond the event horizon. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. The agency is based in Washington, D.C. and is funded by the U.S. taxpayer.

title: NASA’s Apollo Samples, LRO Help Scientists Predict Moonquakes
summary: Moonquakes pose little risk to astronauts during a mission lasting just a few days. But their effects on longer-term lunar surface assets could be significant.
detailed_news: Scientists are working on methods to determine the frequency of moonquakes along active faults there. Moonquakes are rare, with the most powerful ones, about magnitude 5.0, occurring near the surface. Study: A magnitude 3.0 moonquake occurs along the Lee Lincoln fault about every 5.6 million years. The tracks left behind indicated that the boulders may have rolled downhill after being shaken loose during a moonquake on the Lee-Lincoln fault. The chances that a quake would have shaken the Taurus-Littrow valley on any given day while the Apollo 17 astronauts were there are 1 in 20 million. NASA also is planning to send more seismometers to the Moon.

title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 Astronauts to Discuss Science Mission
summary: After spending almost five months in space, NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 astronauts will discuss their science mission aboard the International Space Station during a news conference at 4:15 p.m. EDT, Wednesday, Aug. 20, from the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, and JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi […]
detailed_news: NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, and JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi will answer questions about their mission. The crew spent 146 days aboard the orbiting laboratory, traveling nearly 62,795,205 million miles. While living and working aboard the station, the crew completed hundreds of science experiments and technology demonstrations.

title: Say Cheese!
summary: Eleven International Space Station crew members gather inside the space station’s Unity module for a portrait on Aug. 3, 2025. In the front row, from left are, Kimiya Yui of JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency), Zena Cardman of NASA, Oleg Platonov of Roscosmos, and Mike Fincke of NASA. In the second row are, Nichole Ayers […]
detailed_news: Eleven International Space Station crew members gather inside the space station’s Unity module for a portrait on Aug. 3, 2025. In the front row, from left are, Kimiya Yui of JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency), Zena Cardman of NASA, Oleg Platonov of Roscosmos, and Mike Fincke of NASA.

title: MetOp-SG-A1 and Sentinel-5: from cleanroom to space
summary: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission –  has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European spaceport in French Guiana. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time).
detailed_news: MetOp-SG-A1 is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites. It hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission, which delivers daily global data on air pollutants and atmospheric trace gases. Ariane 6 is Europe’s heavy launcher and a key element of ESA's efforts to ensure autonomous access to space.

title: The Exploration Company Taps Agile Space for Nyx Earth Thrusters
summary:
The Exploration Company has awarded US-based Agile Space a contract to provide thrusters for its Nyx Earth spacecraft. Founded in 2021, The Exploration Company is developing a reusable spacecraft that will initially be used to transport cargo to and from the International Space Station under a European Space Agency contract. An initial mission to the […]
The post The Exploration Company Taps Agile Space for Nyx Earth Thrusters appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The Exploration Company has awarded a contract to Agile Space for thrusters for its Nyx Earth spacecraft. The company is developing a reusable spacecraft that will initially be used to transport cargo to and from the International Space Station. An initial mission to the orbiting laboratory is expected to take place no later than 2028.

title: NASA’s Stennis Space Center Employees Receive NASA Honor Awards
summary: NASA Stennis Space Center Director John Bailey and Deputy Director Christine Powell presented NASA Honor Awards to employees during an onsite ceremony Aug. 13. One NASA Stennis employee received NASA’s Outstanding Leadership Medal. The medal is awarded to government employees for notable leadership accomplishments that have significantly influenced the NASA mission. Marvin Horne of Fulton, […]
detailed_news: Three NASA Stennis employees received NASA’s Exceptional Service Medal. Marvin Horne of Fulton, Maryland, received the NASA Outstanding Leadership Medal. Barry Robinson of Slidell, Louisiana, was awarded the medal in absentia. Jared Grover of Diamondhead, Mississippi, led various testing and facility preparation efforts. Eight NASA Stennis employees received NASA’s Exceptional Achievement Medal. Medal is awarded to any government employee for a significant specific achievement or substantial improvement in operations, efficiency, service, financial savings, science, or technology which contributes to the mission of NASA. Leslie Anderson of Picayune, Mississippi received the NASA Exceptional achievement Medal in absentia. Four NASA Stennis employees received NASA’s Early Career Achievement Medal. Dale Woolridge of Slidell, Louisiana received the NASA Exceptional Achievement Medal in absentia. Briou Bourgeois played a key role in modifying the liquid oxygen tanking process during the SLS core stage series. Andrew Bracey of Picayune, Mississippi, received the NASA Silver Achievement Medal for contributions. He has provided critical design support for work related to Green Run testing of the new SLS (Space Launch System) exploration upper stage. Bracey also has been crucial to the NASA Stennis vision of supporting commercial aerospace testing.

title: NASA Glenn Earns Commercial Invention of the Year Award
summary: NASA’s Inventions and Contributions Board (ICB) has awarded Commercial Invention of the Year to NASA Glenn Research Center’s GRX-810: A 3D Printable Alloy Designed for Extreme Environments.   NASA Alloy GRX–810, an oxide dispersion strengthened (ODS) alloy, can endure temperatures over 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. It is more malleable and can survive more than 1,000 times longer […]
detailed_news: NASA Glenn Research Center’s GRX-810: A 3D Printable Alloy Designed for Extreme Environments. GRX–810, an oxide dispersion strengthened (ODS) alloy, can endure temperatures over 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. It is more malleable and can survive more than 1,000 times longer than existing state-of-the-art alloys.

title: NASA Tests Research Aircraft to Improve Air Taxi Flight Controls
summary: Flying the friendly skies may one day include time-saving trips in air taxis to get from point A to point B – and NASA researchers are currently working to make that future a reality. They are using wind tunnel and flight tests to gather data on an electric Vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) scaled-down small […]
detailed_news: NASA researchers are using wind tunnel and flight tests to gather data on an electric Vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) small aircraft. The small aircraft weighs 38 pounds with a wingspan of six feet and has 24 independently moving components. The testing is ongoing at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. missions Artemis Aeronautics STEM Explore NASA’s History NASA: The Journey Through Space and Beyond. Artemis: The journey through space and beyond.

title: FLEX instrument meets its satellite
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: FLEX’s fluorescence imaging spectrometer is called FLORIS for short. It is designed to map vegetation fluorescence around the globe and quantify photosynthetic activity and plant stress. The next step is to carry out a final series of tests ahead of the launch scheduled in 2026.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral
summary: The Starlink 10-20 mission will add another 28 broadband internet satellites to SpaceX’s megaconstellation. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled at 6:47 a.m. EDT (1047 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing to launch a batch of 28 of its Starlink V2 Mini satellites into low Earth orbit minutes before sunrise on Thursday morning. It’s targeting the liftoff of its Falcon 9 rocket on the Starlink 10-20 mission from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 6:47 a.m. EDT. This will be the 69th orbital launch from Florida so far this year.

title: Trump Issues Executive Order on Commercial Space
summary: President Trump issued a broad Executive Order this afternoon addressing commercial space activities overseen by the Department of Transportation and the Department of Commerce.  Among the provisions, DOT must reform […]
detailed_news: President Trump issued a broad Executive Order this afternoon addressing commercial space activities. DOT must reform regulations for commercial space launch and reentry and several agencies working together to advance development of spaceport infrastructure. The Executive Order, “ Enabling Competition in the Commercial Space Industry, ” is reminiscent of Trump’s Space Policy Directive-3.

title: U.S. Transportation Secretary & Acting NASA Administrator Sean P. Duffy Joins President Trump Executive Order Signing to Boost U.S. Space Competitiveness
summary: U.S. Transportation Secretary and acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy joined President Donald J. Trump at the White House Wednesday for the historic signing of the Executive Order (EO), “Enabling Competition in the Commercial Space Industry.” “People think the Department of Transportation (DOT) is just planes, trains, and automobiles – but we have a critical role […]
detailed_news: U.S. Transportation Secretary and acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy joined President Donald J. Trump at the White House Wednesday for the historic signing of the Executive Order. “People think the Department of Transportation (DOT) is just planes, trains, and automobiles – but we have a critical role to play in unlocking the final frontier,” said Duffy.

title: Ship 37 completes a Spin Prime test following Engine Swap
summary:
The target launch date for Flight 10 is one step closer after the retest of…
The post Ship 37 completes a Spin Prime test following Engine Swap appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has completed a pair of static fires on Pad 1 (A) and returned Ship 37 to Mega Bay 2 for more engine testing. The target launch date for Flight 10 is one step closer after the retest of Ship 37, which followed an engine change. The launch pad teams quickly uninstalled all of the modifications and re-installing 16 out of 20 booster hold-down clamps. Ship 37 completed a six engine spin prime during the second closure of Mega Bay 1. With this testing completed, Ship 37 will likely roll back to Mega Bay 2 for final launch preparations and checkouts. SpaceX will likely load the dummy Starlinks for the fourth time on a ship, in an attempt to test the pez deploy system in space.

The RASC-AL challenge fuels innovation for aerospace systems concepts, analogs, and technology prototyping by bridging […]

title: Alligator Goes for a Swim
summary: An alligator moves through a brackish waterway at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida in this May 8, 2017, photo. The center shares space with the Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge. More than 330 native and migratory bird species, 25 mammals, 117 fishes and 65 amphibians and reptiles call NASA Kennedy and the wildlife refuge […]
detailed_news: The center shares space with the Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge. More than 330 native and migratory bird species, 25 mammals, 117 fishes and 65 amphibians and reptiles call NASA Kennedy and the wildlife refuge home. The refuge is also home to over 1,000 known plant species.

title: Portugal’s ASC Granted Licence for Santa Maria Launch Centre
summary:
Portugal has granted the Atlantic Spaceport Consortium a licence to build and operate a rocket launch facility on the island of Santa Maria. The Atlantic Spaceport Consortium (ASC) was founded in 2019 with the goal of developing a commercial spaceport on the island of Santa Maria, 1,500 kilometres off the Portuguese mainland. In September 2024, […]
The post Portugal’s ASC Granted Licence for Santa Maria Launch Centre appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The Atlantic Spaceport Consortium (ASC) was founded in 2019 with the goal of developing a commercial spaceport on the island of Santa Maria. In September 2024, the company showcased the island’s suitability as a launch site by launching two small solid-fuel rockets that it had developed in-house. In July, ASC signed an agreement with Poland-based rocket builder SpaceForest to launch its 11.5-metre Perun rocket from the island.

title: Tracking the climate-driven shift in Antarctic plankton from space
summary: Combining 25 years of space-based data with ocean sampling, scientists have uncovered a change in the microscopic organisms that underpin the Southern Ocean’s food chain and carbon storage.
detailed_news: Study uses satellite observations to study phytoplankton in the Southern Ocean. Findings could have effects on the marine food web and role as a carbon sink. Researchers analysed marker pigments in more than 14 000 in-situ samples to investigate changes in species composition over a 25-year period. Phytoplankton biomass and pigment diversity have been designated an essential climate variable. Long-term satellite records are needed to understand the cycles of these organisms. ESA’s climate initiative is establishing a project called Phyto-CCI. It aims to generate global records of phytop lankton types from space.

title: International Space Station undergoes crew handover, change of command
summary:
Expedition 73 aboard the International Space Station (ISS) continues to perform its scheduled science and…
The post International Space Station undergoes crew handover, change of command appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Crew Dragon Endeavour set a new record for the shortest time from launch to docking. The Station has a new commander and a new set of crew members on the U.S. side of the complex. Crew-11’s astronauts settled into life aboard the orbiting outpost. Four astronauts departed this week to conclude their tour of duty on ISS. Crew-11 may be tasked with a spacewalk on the U.S. segment that Crew-10 did not do. Japan’s HTV-X is scheduled to make its first flight to ISS no earlier than this October. CRS-33, using Cargo Dragon C211 on its third flight, is currently set to launch on Thursday. While Expedition 73 continues, decisions are being made on the ground about the coming budget for the Station. VAST’s Haven Demo, designed to test key systems aboard its coming space station, is scheduled to fly later this year. Thales Alenia in Europe has completed the shell of Axiom Space's first space station module.

title: NASA’s Hubble Uncovers Rare White Dwarf Merger Remnant
summary: An international team of astronomers has discovered a cosmic rarity: an ultra-massive white dwarf star resulting from a white dwarf merging with another star, rather than through the evolution of a single star. This discovery, made by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope’s sensitive ultraviolet observations, suggests these rare white dwarfs may be more common than previously […]
detailed_news: Astronomers used Hubble’s Cosmic Origins Spectrograph to investigate a white dwarf called WD 0525+526. Located 128 light-years away, it is 20% more massive than the Sun. In visible light, the spectrum of the white dwarf's atmosphere resembled that of a typical white dwarf. But Hubble's ultraviolet vision revealed that it had a very different history from what we would have guessed. The high temperature and low carbon abundance mean that identifying this white dwarf as the product of a merger would have been impossible without Hubble’s sensitivity to ultraviolet light. Because WD 0525+526's origin was revealed only once astronomers glimpsed its ultraviolet spectrum, it's likely that other seemingly “normal” white dwarfs are actually the result of cosmic collisions.

title: No Earth-like atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 d
summary: The exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 d intrigues astronomers looking for possibly habitable worlds beyond our solar system because it is similar in size to Earth, rocky, and resides in an area around its star where liquid water on its surface is theoretically possible. But according to a new study using data from the NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope, it does not have an Earth-like atmosphere.
detailed_news: The TRAPPIST-1 system contains seven Earth-sized worlds orbiting the most common type of star in the galaxy: a red dwarf. Webb’s NIRSpec (Near-Infrared Spectrograph) instrument did not detect molecules that are common in Earth's atmosphere, like water, methane, or carbon dioxide. Webb observations of the outer TRAPPIST-1 planets are ongoing, which hold both potential and peril. On the one hand, planets e, f, g, and h may have better chances of having atmospheres because they are further away from the energetic eruptions of their host star. But their distance and colder environment will make atmospheric signatures more difficult to detect.

title: NASA’s SpaceX-33 Resupply Mission Launches Research to Station
summary: Research traveling to the International Space Station aboard NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission includes testing 3D bioprinting of an implantable medical device, observing behavior of engineered liver tissues, examining microgravity’s effects on bone-forming cells, and additional 3D printing of metal in space. The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft is scheduled to launch to the orbiting laboratory […]
detailed_news: The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft is scheduled to launch to the orbiting laboratory in late August. For nearly 25 years, the International Space Station has provided research capabilities used by scientists from over 110 countries to conduct more than 4,000 groundbreaking experiments in microgravity. Research conducted aboard the space station advances future space exploration. This investigation is a continuation of ESA’s efforts to develop in-space manufacturing and materials recycling capabilities. The ESA investigation team includes Airbus Defence and Space SAS and the User Support Centre CADMOS in France. Learn more about the research aboard the International Space Station at: www.nasa.gov/iss-science.

title: Webb Narrows Atmospheric Possibilities for Earth-sized Exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 d
summary: The exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 d intrigues astronomers looking for possibly habitable worlds beyond our solar system because it is similar in size to Earth, rocky, and resides in an area around its star where liquid water on its surface is theoretically possible. But according to a new study using data from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, […]
detailed_news: The TRAPPIST-1 system is located 40 light-years away and was revealed as the record-holder for most Earth-sized rocky planets around a single star in 2017. Scientists are motivated to seek signs of atmospheres because red dwarf stars are the most common stars in our galaxy. If planets can hold on to an atmosphere, under waves of harsh stellar radiation, they could, as the saying goes, make it anywhere. The James Webb Space Telescope is the world’s premier space science observatory. Webb is solving mysteries in our solar system, looking beyond to distant worlds around other stars. It studies every phase in the… Exoplanets Stars Universe NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity.

title: NASA Glenn Offers Students Work-Based Learning Through Engineering Institute
summary: This summer, NASA’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland hosted the NASA Glenn High School Engineering Institute, a free, work-based learning experience designed to prepare rising high school juniors and seniors for careers in the aerospace workforce.  “The institute immerses students in NASA’s work, providing essential career readiness tools for future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics-focused […]
detailed_news: NASA Glenn Research Center in Cleveland hosted the NASA Glenn High School Engineering Institute. The free, work-based learning experience prepares rising high school juniors and seniors for careers in the aerospace workforce. Students used authentic NASA mission content and collaborated with Glenn’s technical experts. They gained a deeper understanding of the engineering design process.

title: NASA Glenn Shoots for the Stars During WNBA All-Star Weekend
summary: From astronauts to athletes, researchers to referees, and communicators to coaches, NASA is much like basketball – we all train to reach the top of our game. Staff from NASA’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland drove home this point during the “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis, July 17-19. […]
detailed_news: “All-Star Shoot for the Stars’ event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis, July 17-19. Event highlighted NASA technology while illuminating the intersection of sports and STEM. Highlights included a detailed Orion exhibit, a new spacesuit display featuring five full-scale spacesuits and virtual reality demonstrations.

title: NASA Glenn Names University Student Design Challenge Winner
summary: A student team from The Ohio State University secured first place in NASA Glenn Research Center’s 2025-2026 University Student Design Challenge for their innovative design aimed at managing fluids in space. The team will develop a working prototype as part of their senior capstone project during the upcoming academic year.  On June 23, the team […]
detailed_news: The Ohio State University team secured first place in NASA Glenn Research Center’s 2025-2026 University Student Design Challenge. The team will develop a working prototype as part of their senior capstone project during the upcoming academic year. NASA Glenn engineers Nancy Hall and John McQuillan served as student mentors and technical advisors.

title: MetOp-SG-A1 and Sentinel-5 launch highlights
summary: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission –  has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time).

The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time) It is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites.

title: EDGX Secures €2.3M to Build AI In-Orbit Data Processing System
summary:
Belgium-based startup EDGX announced on 11 August that it had secured €2.3 million in seed funding to develop a high-performance, AI-capable on-board computer that will process data collected by a satellite’s sensors directly in orbit. Founded in 2023, EDGX is developing its Sterna on-board computer and the SpaceFeather software that will power it. It aims […]
The post EDGX Secures €2.3M to Build AI In-Orbit Data Processing System appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Belgium-based startup EDGX announced on 11 August that it had secured €2.3 million in seed funding to develop a high-performance, AI-capable on-board computer. The company is currently preparing for its initial demonstration mission, dubbed Early Bird, which is scheduled to launch in February 2026 aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9. According to the company, it has already secured a €1.1 million commercial contract with an undisclosed satellite operator.

title: MetOp-SG-A1 and Sentinel-5 launch on Ariane 6
summary: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission –  has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time).
detailed_news: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission – has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time) It is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites.

title: First MetOp-SG and Sentinel-5 launched
summary: Ushering in a new era of weather and climate monitoring from polar orbit, the first in a new series of satellites, MetOp Second Generation, has been lofted into orbit aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana. As part of this new satellite’s sophisticated instrument package is the new Copernicus Sentinel-5 instrument, which is designed to deliver critical data on air pollutants, ozone and climate-related gases.
detailed_news: First in a new series of satellites, MetOp Second Generation, has been lofted into orbit aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana. As part of this new satellite’s sophisticated instrument package is the new Copernicus Sentinel-5 instrument, which is designed to deliver critical data on air pollutants. Each of the three pairs consists of an A-type and B-type satellite. They carry complementary state-of-the-art instruments to provide high-resolution measurements of temperature, precipitation, clouds and winds for weather forecasting and climate analysis. Each MetOp-SG satellite is fitted with an extra thruster, enabling it to self-destruct in Earth’s atmosphere when the mission is complete. Main stage and solid rocket boosters are responsible for the first phase of flight. The stage is powered by the Vulcain 2.1 engine (fuelled by liquid oxygen and hydrogen), with the main thrust at liftoff provided by the P120C boosters. The upper stage will fire two times to reach the required orbit for this mission.

title: ULA launches Vulcan rocket on first Space Force mission
summary: Equipped with four solid-fuel strap-on boosters for additional takeoff power, the 198-foot-tall Vulcan's two methane-fueled BE-4 engines thundered to life at 8:56p.m. EDT, instantly propelling the rocket away from pad 41 at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.
detailed_news: United Launch Alliance fired off it’s first fully operational Vulcan rocket Tuesday. The rocket put on a spectacular sky-lighting show as it roared aloft atop nearly 3 million pounds of thrust. At least two satellites were believed to be on board: one classified spacecraft and an experimental satellite. United Launch Alliance chief executive Tory Bruno spoke with Spaceflight Now’s Stephen Clark at the 32nd Space Symposium in Colorado Springs. ULA President and CEO Tory Bruno said the Vulcan's first stage, using high-performance BE-4 engines, is particularly well suited for launching heavy military payloads into hard-to-reach orbits.

title: ULA’s Vulcan Centaur Lifts Off on First National Security Mission
summary: ULA’s new Vulcan Centaur rocket lifted off on a national security mission for the first time this evening. One payload aboard the U.S. Space Force’s USSF-106 mission is the Navigation […]
detailed_news: The U.S. Space Force’s USSF-106 mission is the Navigation Technology Satellite-3 that is testing new technologies for future satellite navigation systems like GPS. NTS-3 is a small spacecraft on a very big rocket being launched in one of its most capable configurations. The USSF is not saying what else is aboard. ULA ended live coverage of the launch before reaching orbit. After intense debate in the Senate, then-Senator Bill Nelson brokered a deal in 2016 setting limits on the number of RD-180s ULA could buy and how long they could be used for military missions. ULA had already begun working on a new rocket by then, reaching agreement in 2014 with Jeff Bezos’s Blue Origin to build the engines.

title: B1091 “A Heavy Core in Falcon 9 Clothing”
summary:
SpaceX’s recent launch involved another successful landing of its Falcon 9 booster, but this time…
The post B1091 “A Heavy Core in Falcon 9 Clothing” appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX’s recent launch involved another successful landing of its Falcon 9 booster, but this time marked a Falcon Heavy center core booster launching and landing as a single-stick Falcon 9 rocket. The booster, designated B1091, powered the KF-02 mission, deploying 24 satellites for Amazon's Project Kuiper broadband constellation into low Earth orbit. The launch occurred on August 11, 2025, at 8:35 a.m. ET from Space Launch Complex 40. SpaceX has repurposed Falcon Heavy side boosters for Falcon 9 missions in the past, including the inaugural Falcon Heavy flight in 2018. The primary deterrent has been the added mass from reinforcements, estimated at 10-20% more than a standard Falcon 9 booster. During its return, observers noticed evidence of the booster’s heavier build during the KF-02 landing.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4624-4626: A Busy Weekend at the Boxwork
summary: Written by Alex Innanen, Atmospheric Scientist at York University Earth planning date: Friday, Aug. 8, 2025 We continue to progress through the boxwork structures, arriving today at the “peace sign” ridges we were aiming for in our last drive. We’re spending the first two sols of the weekend at this location, learning everything we can […]
detailed_news: Curiosity has arrived at the “peace sign” ridges we were aiming for in our last drive. The environmental science group (ENV) is also taking a dust-devil movie and a surpahorizon cloud movie. ChemCam will use AEGIS to autonomously pick a LIBS target, we’ll have a 360-degree survey to try to catch dust devils.

title: NASA IXPE’s ‘Heartbeat Black Hole’ Measurements Challenge Current Theories
summary: Written by Michael Allen An international team of astronomers using NASA’s IXPE (Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer), has challenged our understanding of what happens to matter in the direct vicinity of a black hole. With IXPE, astronomers can study incoming X-rays and measure the polarization, a property of light that describes the direction of its electric […]
detailed_news: Astronomers used NASA’s IXPE to measure a 9.1% polarization degree for black hole IGR J17091-3624. The polarization degree is a measurement of how aligned those vibrations are to each other. Despite how bright the corona is, at some 28,000 light-years from Earth, it remains far too small and distant to capture an image of it. IXPE is led by NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. BAE Systems, Inc., headquartered in Falls Church, Virginia, manages spacecraft operations. The Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer (IXPE) is a space observatory built to discover the secrets of some of the most…

title: A Tapestry of Tales: 10th Anniversary Reflections from NASA’s OCO-2 Mission
summary: When woven together, the tapestry of experiences of staff and scientists provide the complete picture of OCO-2. Breathe in… Breathe out. This simple rhythm sets the foundation of life on Earth – and it’s a pattern that a NASA satellite has been watching from space for over a decade. On July 2, 2024, NASA’s Orbiting […]
detailed_news: On July 2, 2024, NASA’s Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 (OCO-2) celebrated 10 years since its launch. OCO-2 is now viewed as the gold standard for carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) measurements from space. Scientists from around the world have come together to bring the important data from this satellite to the broader community. The first launch in 2009 ended in failure – when a faulty launch vehicle doomed the first OCO to a watery grave. In the aftermath, the OCO community were left in limbo, unsure if the project would survive. OCO-2 can detect the faint glow given off by plants during photosynthesis. This glow offers a fast, sensitive indicator of plant health – see Figure 2 . OCO-2 and MODIS provide a global dataset of plant photosynthesis far beyond what either satellite could produce on its own. OCO-2’s synergy with its A-Train counterpart, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’S Aqua platform, makes the data even more powerful. OCO-2 and OCO-3 provide complementary perspectives on Earth’s carbon cycle and plant health at space and time resolutions that have not been possible from space before. The satellite's high-precision measurements can now detect CO 2 linked not just to countries, but large cities, industrial zones, and even individual power plants – all while researchers continue perfecting efforts to identify contributions from city sectors. The Total Carbon Column Observing Network (TCCON) of Fourier Transform Spectrometers (FTS) measure CO 2 over snow-covered ground. OCO-2 was being used to develop early drought forecasts. The “ground truth” data collected at these field sites help to ensure that the satellite is accurately measuring “Earth’s breathing” During the 2015–2016 El Niño, large tropical forests temporarily transformed into net carbon sources. OCO-2 captured the increase in atmospheric CO 2 and scientists used this data to refine estimates of how these events contribute to the global carbon budget. Scientists are combining the satellite data with wind models and urban maps to trace CO 2 to its sources.

title: A Gigantic Jet Caught on Camera: A Spritacular Moment for NASA Astronaut Nicole Ayers!
summary: Astronaut Captures Rare Gigantic Jet from Space On July 3, 2025, NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers photographed an extraordinary sight from the International Space Station — a rare gigantic jet, a powerful electrical discharge shooting from the top of a thunderstorm into the upper atmosphere. Often mistaken for sprites, these towering lightning events bridge clouds and space, depositing massive electrical charges. Learn how gigantic jets differ from other Transient Luminous Events and how you can submit your own sightings to Spritacular.org.
detailed_news: NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers captured a rare form of a Transient Luminous Events (TLEs) — a gigantic jet. Gigantic jets are a powerful type of electrical discharge that extends from the top of a thunderstorm into the upper atmosphere. Sprites, on the other hand, are one of the most commonly observed types of TLEs.

title: LIVE COVERAGE! Vulcan Set To Launch First U.S. National Security Mission
summary: LIVE COVERAGE! Vulcan Set To Launch First U.S. National Security Mission
detailed_news: The USSF-106 mission, flying for the U.S. Space Force’s Space Systems Command, is scheduled to lift off tonight from Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida. The launch window runs from 7:59 to 8:59 p.m. EDT (2359–0059 UTC), with liftoff targeted within that one-hour period.

title: Hubble Captures a Tarantula
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image captures incredible details in the dusty clouds of a star-forming factory called the Tarantula Nebula. Most of the nebulae Hubble images are in our galaxy, but this nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. The Large Magellanic […]
detailed_news: The Tarantula Nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. This image is very close to a rare type of star called a Wolf–Rayet star . Wolf– Rayet stars are massive stars that have lost their outer shell of hydrogen.

title: NASA Roman Core Survey Will Trace Cosmic Expansion Over Time
summary: NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will be a discovery machine, thanks to its wide field of view and resulting torrent of data. Scheduled to launch no later than May 2027, with the team working toward launch as early as fall 2026, its near-infrared Wide Field Instrument will capture an area 200 times larger than […]
detailed_news: The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will be a discovery machine. Its near-infrared Wide Field Instrument will capture an area 200 times larger than the Hubble Space Telescope’s infrared camera. Roman will devote about 75% of its science observing time over its five-year primary mission. High-Latitude Time-Domain Survey will be split into two imaging “tiers” — a wide tier that covers more area and a deep tier that will focus on a smaller area for a longer time to detect fainter objects. The observations will take place in two areas, one in the northern sky and another in the southern sky. There will also be a spectroscopic component to this survey, which will be limited to the southern night sky.

title: Ariane 6: preparing flight VA264 for liftoff
summary: MetOp-SG-A1 travelled onboard the Canopée ship. Our teams at the European spaceport in French Guiana have been quite busy making sure both the rocket and the payloads are ready for flight VA264.
detailed_news: MetOp-SG-A1 is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites. Will provide global observations from polar orbit for weather forecasting and climate analysis for more than 20 years. Will launch on an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana on August 2025.

title: Live coverage: ULA to launch first national security mission on a Vulcan rocket
summary: The mission, dubbed USSF-106, will be the first Vulcan rocket launch since the vehicle was certified by the United States Space Force in late March. Liftoff from pad 41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is schedule for 7:59 p.m. EDT (2359 UTC).
detailed_news: The United States Space Force (USSF)-106 mission is scheduled to launch from Cape Canaveral on Tuesday. The rocket will carry a pair of satellites to geoscynchronous orbit. The launch marks ULA's return to launching payloads as part of the National Security Space Launch (NSSL) program. The USSF-106 mission is comprised of two satellites. One of those remains a mystery with Space Force officials unwilling to provide any details. The other, which is described as the primary payload onboard the Vulcan rocket is the brainchild of the Air Force Research Laboratory. The mission and launch together come with a $250 million price tag. NTS-3 is being tested in the laboratory as well as out in the field. Some of the learns from this, like calibrating a spot beam antenna, can be applied to the next generation of GPS satellites, called GPS 3-F. The prime contractor that manufactured the satellite is L3Harris Technologies.
